article.body: President Donald Trump likes to paint Joe Biden as beholden to the progressive wing of the Democratic Party, a âTrojan Horseâ for the left. Is that accurate? As Biden prepares to accept the presidential nomination on Thursday, give Trump partial credit for spotting a leftward tilt by the former vice president. But only partial. Biden has indeed moved to the left in some of his policy proposals. Yet on others, the 77-year-old veteran Democrat hasnât budged. Having fought a bitter primary-season battle with progressives Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren, Biden wound up adopting some of those senatorsâ ideas. For example, Biden added to his own agenda Sandersâ proposal to make public college tuition-free for students whose families make less than $125,000. He backed Warrenâs plan to make it easier to file for bankruptcy. And Biden recently rolled out an environmental plan that was more aggressive than what he proposed during the campaign. See:Biden calls for $2 trillion in clean-energy spending and zero power-plant emissions by 2035. âHeâs moved on some issues quite decidedly to the left,â says Larry Jacobs, a political scientist at the University of Minnesota. But Biden hasnât gone as far as some policies in the Green New Deal, the climate-change-fighting plan of progressives such as Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. While his running mate Sen. Kamala Harris said last year during a debate that there was âno questionâ she was in favor of banning fracking, Biden would do that only for oil and gas production from federal lands. And the former vice president hasnât signed on to Medicare for All, preferring instead to build on the Affordable Care Act that became law under President Barack Obama. Still, Trumpâs line of attack is to paint the longtime Democrat as an extremist. âJoe Biden and Kamala Harris would DESTROY America,â read a Trump campaign fundraising email on Monday, the day the Democratsâ convention kicked off. âTheir Socialist Convention this week is only a preview of whatâs to come,â the campaign said. Trump is spending the week lobbing such attacks in four battleground states, counterprogramming the convention. Watch:Joe Biden officially nominated by virtual roll call at DNC. Trump, facing unemployment of more than 10% as the coronavirus continues to wrack the U.S. economy, claims that Biden and Harris would sink stocks SPX, +0.87% Â and even cause a depression via their economic policies, such as raising the corporate tax rate to 28% from 21% and imposing higher rates on individuals. Wall Street analysts offer a much more nuanced picture. At least one has said another Trump term has the potential to cause a double-dip recession if the coronavirus crisis is mishandled. And analysts say there are sector winners and losers under a potential Biden presidency, with utilities and health care poised to benefit, and energy and financials possibly suffering. To be sure, Bidenâs ability to make sweeping policy changes in health care or tax policy would depend on the makeup of Congress. Republicansâ continued hold on the Senate could stymie major ambitions â but the GOPâs ceding the chamber to Democrats would open a path for Bidenâs plans, especially with a Democratic-controlled House. A tug of war over Bidenâs policies appears poised to continue if he gets elected. Speaking at the Democratic convention on Monday night, former Ohio Gov. John Kasich, a Republican, argued against those in his party and independents who worry that Biden âmay turn sharp left and leave them behind.â âI donât believe that,â he said. âNo one pushes Joe around.â Some activists, meanwhile, say they intend to try to do just that. Varshini Prakash, co-founder of the climate-advocacy group the Sunrise Movement, called Bidenâs proposal to stop fracking on federal lands âa strong step,â but said the former vice president can go much farther on issues affecting the environment. âNo matter what, weâre got to push Joe Biden to increase and improve his ambition,â Prakash, whose organization wants to âmake the Green New Deal the law of the land,â told MarketWatch.
